column2: david prager branner writes : > there is talk again on the linguist list about the "" great eskimo snow > hoax "" . > > . . . i would like to hear from an inuit > or tlingit specialist on just what the snow situation really is in these > languages . frankly
column3: i find it rather hard to believe . > > rural southern chinese dialects have lots of words for different kinds of > rice
column4: . . . > . . . > so why should n't inuit > have a dozen or more words for different kinds of cold precipitation ? when geoff pullum 's book
column5: ' the great eskimo vocabulary hoax
column6: ' came out
column7: i started getting quite a number of inquiries from journalists about "" words for 's now ' in eskimo . "" that motivated me to prepare the appended item . please feel free to pass it around . tony woodbury * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * counting eskimo words for snow : a citizen 's guide lexemes referring to snow and snow-related notions in steven a . jacobson 's ( 1984 ) yup ' ik eskimo dictionary [ 1 ] anthony c . woodbury university of texas at austin july 1991 this is a list of lexemes referring to snow and related notions in one eskimo language
column8: central alaskan yupik ( or just yup ' ik eskimo ) . it is spoken by about 13
column9: 000 people in the coast and river areas of southwestern alaska from norton sound to bristol bay . it is one of five eskimo languages . ( of these five
column10: probably the best-known is inuit
column11: spoken in a series of well-differentiated dialects ranging from northern alaska
column12: all across the canadian far north
column13: and up to the coast of greenland . while the term inuit is preferred to eskimo by many in canada
column14: the term is retained here because ( a ) it properly refers to any eskimo group
column15: not only the inuit ; and ( b ) its use is widespread in native communities in alaska . ) this is a list of lexemes rather than of words . roughly
column16: a lexeme can be thought of as an independent vocabulary item or dictionary entry . it 's different from a word since a lexeme can give rise to more than one distinctly inflected word . thus english has a single lexeme _ speak _ which gives rise to inflected forms like _ speaks _
column17: _ spoke _
column18: and _ spoken _ . it 's especially important to count lexemes rather than words when talking about eskimo languages . that 's because they are inflectionally so complicated that each single noun lexeme may have about 280 distinct inflected forms
column19: while each verb lexeme may have over 1000 ! obviously
column20: that would put the number of snow words through the roof very quickly . the list is organized according to lexeme * meanings * . perhaps somewhat arbitrarily i have counted fifteen of them
column21: placing within each of them noun and / or verb lexemes having the same basic sense . and perhaps even more arbitrarily
column22: i ' ve grouped these fifteen meanings into four larger sets . but the most arbitrary decision of all is left to the discretion of the reader-the decision of how to count the lexemes themselves . here are some of the problems you face : ( a ) are all fifteen lexeme meanings really 's now ' - meanings ? that is
column23: do words with these meanings really count for you as words for snow ? [ 2 ] ( b ) there are some synonyms present - - alternative lexemes with the same meaning
column24: like garbage vs . trash in english . are you going to count them separately
column25: or together ? ( c ) if you decided to count synonyms together
column26: will you also count together both of the members of noun-verb pairs having basically the same meaning ? ( the members are
column27: technically speaking
column28: separate lexemes since partly idiosyncratic morphological changes mark the verbal forms
column29: and must therefore be listed separately in any truly informative dictionary
column30: as indeed jacobson 's dictionary does . ) ( d ) following jacobson
column31: i ' ve specially labelled those lexemes that only occur in a small subpart of the central alaskan yupik - speaking region . are you going to try to make counts for each separate dialect ? if yes
column32: you will wonder if you really have enough information to do so . ( you ' re not alone in this-such information is difficult to compile

column42: university of alaska
column43: fairbanks . 2 . the indeterminacy and difficulty of this question is due to the fact that words do n't merely match pre-existing things in the world . rather
column44: they shape and encapsulate ideas about things - - how they are categorized ( compare dog vs . canine )
column45: how we are interacting with them ( compare sheep vs . mutton )
column46: how the word functions grammatically ( compare the noun cow vs . the adjective bovine )

column2: I'm in favor of forests.  I'm not in favor of messing

column1: > with natural processes that forests and trees have evolved over millions of

> Every time I look toward the west from my house I see the result of overly
> aggressive tree saving.  The Cerro Grande fire that destroyed many (200+)
> houses and an area bigger than Boston.
> The Santa Fe watershed
column2: which has as many as 1200 trees per acre in an area

column1: > that if left to nature would have 30-60 trees per acre.  When the Forest

> lovers stopped the program with law suits.
> A number of other projects have been stopped by similar suits.  For
> example
column2: a fire south of Los Alamos that left many usable

column1: > burned
column2: trees standing.  The Forest Service started a project to allow

column1: > loggers to take those trees.  Hah!  The tree lovers stopped that.  Can't

> understand their responsibility in contributing to the number of
> uncontrollable (i.e.
column2: crown fires caused by very dense tree stands and

column1: > under growth) fires by their suits to stop any tree removal from the

Until most people are taking one form of epostage
most people don't have enough incentive to download
and install something that allows them to pay it.
Until most people are set up to pay it
epostage I require closes my mailbox to unknown
senders from whom I want to receive mail. And even
from known senders. Giving someone my email address
doesn't automatically put them in my white list.Hashcash tries to lower the adoption barrier by
removing the need to pay money for epostage.
Instead

signing"" would frustrate spammers while making it

hoping Eudora and some of the other big mail
clients incorporate this kind of feature. The
advantage to putting this in the mail client is
that the required ""hand sign"" can be personalized:  ""Your attempt to email David Friedman is
blocked until you fill in the blank: The
Incredible ______ Machine.""It will be a long time before spammers have a

mind that would work a large percentage of the
time. But I'm not telling. If spammers did figure

challenges. Yeah

1498;Evening Standard - 28 August 2002[Deft use of Fortean Unit of Measurement in 2nd para - MA] 'Lost' penguins found alive
by Charles Miranda A colony of emperor penguins which was thought to have starved to death in
Antarctica has been found alive in a ""big huddle"".  The birds were spotted by the crew of a USAF jet returning to base in New
Zealand. Researchers had feared that a breakaway iceberg the size of Jamaica
had all but wiped out the colony at Cape Crozier on Ross Island.
Thousands of chicks are believed to have died as an increase in sea ice made
it impossible for the adults to find food. A detailed count is planned in
October. Antarctica (New Zealand) chief executive Lou Sanson said: ""The
penguins were in a big huddle. We can now hope that the emperors have had a
successful breeding season over the winter.""
Some 1
